text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another kitchen conundrum for you it's
that time of year it's autumn and that
means it's pumpkin season and it's time
to carve those jack-o'-lanterns one of
my favorite memories from being a kid
was actually carving the pumpkin just to
get the seeds out because that was one
of my favorite snacks and i'm going to
show you the fastest way to get roasted
pumpkin seeds out of your
jack-o'-lantern so i'm just gonna start
by cutting the top creating a nice
design giving it a little bit of a
decorative pattern but you can do this
any which way you'd like oh there you go
now scraping the pumpkin seeds into a
bowl so usually when you're carving a
pumpkin and you're trying to get the
seeds out you have to pick through all
of this pumpkin pulp but i have a trick
for you
so to get some of those seeds out i'd
like to use a sharp sided spoon and what
that means is the side of the spoon it's
not it's not rounded too much it really
helps to kind of carve out all the pulp
in the seeds so this is a large pumpkin
here you can use whatever size you'd
like and i'm going to get out as many
seeds as i can and now here's the trick
there's no need to actually pick through
the pumpkin seeds and separate it from
the pulp you don't have to wash this you
have to dry them you don't have to do
anything we're going to roast them with
all of this stuff on it and it's going
to turn out just perfectly i'm going to
give this mixture a little bit of olive
oil about a tablespoon of olive oil and
a half teaspoon of coarse salt and then
if you just toss this together just make
sure it's nicely combined and then this
goes on a parchment lined cookie sheet
read this out into one nice flat even
layer so have your oven preheated to 300
degrees and these go into the oven and
you want to stir them every 15 minutes
until they're nice and golden-brown and
the pulp which is this is nicely
caramelized and that will take anywhere
from 50 to 60 minutes and I'm going to
show you how perfect they come out so
the pumpkin seeds have been roasted
they're nice and cool right now and you
can see the pulp is nicely caramelized
and the seeds are brown and nutty and
all you have to do now is just use your
hands here use your fingers and
basically gently pull them away from the
caramelized bits of pulp and all of that
pulp stays behind and what's really
great about this is you can use any type
of winter squash or pumpkin for this
butternut squash would be great acorn
squash be a really nice garnish for a
soup or a salad or as I like it just a
tasty tasty snack if you have any
kitchen conundrums that you need solved
write in the comment section below or
reach out to me using the hashtag
kitchen conundrums and I will solve
whatever kitchen problems you may have
you
